'Ihe New Tragedy called

MIRANDOLA,

has been perfoimed four ttmes..—each night has exceeded the former in brittmncy,
fafltio* and numbers**-the voice of the town is with it in an unprecedented manner,
and it will be performedforthe 5th, 6th aud 7th times, on Thurfday, Friday and
.Monday—and three times a week till further notice.

/IARL7WUIN"«7rd FRIAR

BACON

continues to U received with burfts of applaufc and ioceffant laughter—No Pantomimefora ferics of years having obtained more complete fuecefe.

T H E L I F E AND D E A T H
OF

King Richard theThird
Of the Tragedy hitherto acted under The Title of King Kkhatrl III.
more than
halt is the excluiive compofition of C I B B E B . The prefent is an attempt to reftore
(i» piace of his ingenious Alteration) the original Ghanikcr and Language of

SHAKSPtiAKE.
in which no more extraneous matter is retained, than the trifling paflages neceflarv
to connect tbofe fcenes between which omiflions have necdfardy been made for
tiie p.irpofes of reprefentatkm.

^ , i * Managing Cortmlttee most respectfully announce to the Nobility, Gentry and tho Public, that patronized by His Royal Highness
t,
Th» i D
SUSSEX, they have determined on taking a yearly Theatrical Benefit in Aid of the Funds, and the Proprietors of the
Th
J*'.1 * * ° v e o t Garden, having met their views in the most handsome and liberal manner, the same will take place as above.
e on
n
,
K' If t h . above Society was comparatively humble, but fortunately obtaining at an early period the Patronage of their Royal
"* J n 9 8 »e»J^oUKfiS of KENT and SUSSEX, its increase has been rapid; and in the space of a few years has been enabled, from
n v . S S r W * , * l •«• regular Meetings, and the occasional Donations and Subscriptions of the Benevolent, to expend upwards of
>l'h, TJFWiMtfD BIGHT HUNDRED POUNDS AMONG THE VICTIMS OF WANT, exclusive of having presentations i« Midand those National Monuments of Philanthrophy,
t b *'f™*P.*W ) Union School, Tottenham Sheet, St. Marylebone Schoolof Industry,
e
A»fktMtJor the Deaf and Dumb, Kent Road, and Indigent Blind, St. George's Fields.
The Committee respectfully, but confidently, appeal to the Humane for their support on this occasion.

Door* open at haty-past Sh, Performance begin at Seem—Second Price at Nine o'clock.

T H E A T R E ROYAL, COVENT WARDEN.

#3- In consequence of the extraordinary
attraction of

King Henry

IV.

AND

THE

GRAND

Coronation.
The Publick are respectfully informed, that
the Season will be protracted till Wednesday
the 2*3th July: And to accommodate those
Ladies and Gentlemen who have not been
able to obtain Places, fsome of the Performers Bern/its having already been Boughttf

PO
HENRY

IV.

AND

T H E CORONATION,
will be performed next Week, on Monday,
Wednesday\ and Thursday; and on Monday the 9th, and Thursday the 12th
IP* On this particular occasion, an additional Pit Door
will be opened, and Orders of every description refused.

OnStlurday, KINO HENRY IV.—Part It. with the CORONATlO:-.

T H E A T R E ROYAL, COVENT WARDEN.

HIS

MOST

EXCELLENT

MAJESTY
H a s been graciously pleased to Commandthat on the Evening of the CORONATION
Day, this T H E A T R E shall be O P E N E D

Gratuitously
To

THE P U R L I C K .
And in order to prevent Confusion ,;nd secure Comfort to
4he Audience, they will be admitted by T I C K E T S
ONLY, to the different parts of the Theatre, for which
purpose the Box-Office in Hart-Street will be opened on
THURSDAY
next, from Ten till Two o Clock, when
Applicants, on giving their Name and Address, may
obtain Two Tickets, one for a Lady and one for a Gentleman. No more will be issued than for the Number of
Persons the House will conveniently hold.

TOR THESE PERFORMANCES A NEW AND SPLENDID ORCHESTRA,

HANDEL'S SACRED ORATORIO,

T H E MESSIAH,
With the additional Accompaniments
PART I.

by

OvERTUItE.

Recit. Mr. SAPIO—Comfort ye my people. Air—Every valley shall be exalted.
Chorus—And the glory of the Lord ahull be revealed.
Recit. Mr. NELSON—Thus said, the Lord of Hosts. Air—But who may abide the day of his coming f
Chorus—And he shall purify the sons of Levi.
Recit. Mrs. BELLCHAMBERS—Behold ! a virgin shall conceive and bear a Son. Air and Chorus—Ouhou that tellrst good tidings
Recit. Mr. BELLAMY—For, behold ! darkness shall Cover the e rth. Air—The people that vJWked in darkness.
Grand Chorus—For unto us a Child is born.

Ricit Mrs. SALMON—There were shepherds abiding in the field. Chorus—Glory to God
Air, Mrs. SALMON—Rejoice greatly.
Recit. Master LONGHURST—Then shall the eyes of the blind be opened. Air—He shall feed his flock like a shepherd.
Air, Miss STEPHENS—Come unto him, all ye that labour and are heavy laden.
Chorus—His yoke is easy, Ma hi. burden is light.
Between the-First ami Second Parts,

A Concerto on the Clarinet, Mr. WILLMAN,
In which he will introduce (by particular (Jesiie) the favourite Air. " Cease your funning."
VAUT 33.

Chorus— Behold the Lamb of Ood.
Air, Madame VESTttIS--He was despised and rejected of men.
Chorus—Surely he hath borne our griefs. Chorus—AH we, like sheep, have gone astray.
Recit. Mr. SAPIO—All they that see him laugh him to scorn.
Chorus—He trusted in God that he would deliver him.
Recit. Mr. SAPIO—Thy rebuke hath broken his heart.
.iir—Behold and see.
Recit. Miss STEPHENS—He -was cut off out of the land of the living. Air—But thou didst not leave his soul in hell.
Semi-Chorus (the PRINCIPAL SISOERS)—Lift up your h .ids, () ye gates. Full Chorus—-The Lord of Ho^ts.
Rccit. Mr. SAPK)-—L'nto which of the angels. ( bonis.—Let all the angels of God worship him.
Air, Mr. BELL \MY—Thou art gone up on high.
Chorus—The Lord gave the word.
Air, Miss GOODALL—How beautiful are the feet.
Quartetto, Miss GOODALL, Mr. HA WES, Mr. PYNE, and Mr. TINNEY, and Chorus—Their sound is gone out into all land..
Air, Mr. BELLAMY—Why do the nations so furiously rage together?
Chorus—Let us break their bonds asunder.
Recit. Mr. PYNE—He that dwelleth in heaven.
Air—Thou shalt break them with a rod oi iron.
Grand Chorus—Hallelujah I

VAP.T i n .
Air, MiVs STEPHENS—1 know that my Redeemer liveth.
Semi-Chorus (the PRINCIPAL SINGERS)—Since by man came death.
Full Chorus—By man came also the resurrection of the dead.
Semi-Chorus (the PRINCIPAL SINOBRS)—For as in Adam all die. Full Chorus—Even so in Christ shall all be made alive.
Recit. (accompanied,) Mr. BELLAMY—Behold! I tell you a mystery.
Air—The trumpet shall sound. (Trumpet Obligate, Mr. NORTON)
Itecit. Mrs. BELLCHAMBERS—Then shall be brought to pass. Duet, Mrs. BELLCHAMBERS and Mr. PYNE—O Death! where is thy sting ?
Chorus—But thanks be to God.
Air, Mis. GOODALL—If God be for us, who can be against us ?
Grand Chorus—Worthy is the Lamb.

Witt conduct the Pirformance, and preside at the Organ, built by Mr. GRAY.
The B A N D will be numerous and complete in every Department. Leader, Mr. SMART.
The Performers in the Choruses, under the Superintendence of Mr. WATSON, will also be numerous ; and assisted by
the Young Gentlemen of His Majesty's Chapel Royal, St. Paul's Cathedral, and Westminster Abbey.
Books of the Performance to lie had in the Theatre only, Price 10d. Boxes, Places, and Tickets may be taken of Mr. BRANDON, at the Box Office,
from Eleven till Four.
Doors will open at Halt-past Six, and the Performance commence at Seven o'clock.

P A S T II.
As revived in 1816 by SIR GEORGE SMART, and then performed fur the First Time in Public since the Commemoration of the AUTHOR, in
We-tminater Abbey, the celebrated Sacred Oratorio,

I2V E G Y P T . ,

XSRUALEIIJ

COMPOSED BY H A N D E L ,

7

In which many appropriate additional Song, will be introduced from other of his Works, with several Recitative, ant! Aim, taken (by permis».cJh) ftom
the original MS. Score ofthis Oratorio, as performed under Handera immediate DirectionOverture.
Ttecit Mr. PYNE—Now there arose a new king over Egypt.

THE PUBL1CK ARE RESPECTFULLY INFORMED, THAT

During the Recess, THIS THEATRE having undergone S E V E R A L
A L T E R A T I O N S which, the PROPRIETORS flatter themselves,
will be found to contribute to the general Comfort and Convenience* of the P A T R O N S of the DRAMA, '
W I L L BE OPENED
This present TUESDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1822,
When will be performed Skakspeare'i Comedy of

TWELFTH

The Oterture and Musick (with a few exceptions) composed, and the Selections ..ranged by Mr. BISHOP.
In the course of the Comedy will be introduced

Sougs, ©uets, Glees, and Choruses.

The Poetry selected entirely from the Plays, Poems, and Sonnets »f

SHAKSPEARE.

The Theatre overflowed in every part, last night, and
The enthusiastick applause with which most brilliant audiences have
honoured each appearance of
MISS F . H. K E L L Y
being without parallel for many years, the Publick are respectfully
informed that .she will continue her performance of
JULIET
three times in t?rery week, except the next, when previous arrangements will prevent her performing more than twice.
